## Definition

Let $A$ be a monoid with identity element $0$. It is said that $A$ is quasi-Archimedean if $0$ is not an [Archimedean](Archimedean-property.qmd) $A \setminus \{0\}$ is Archimedean.

## Examples

$\circ$ Given a [numerical semigroup](../Basic-concepts/Numerical-semigroup.qmd) $S$, it holds that $S$ is Quasi-Archimedean. First, $s = 0$ is not an Archimedean. On the other hand, let $F(S)$ be the [Frobenius number](../Basic-concepts/Frobenius-number.qmd) of $S$. Given $x, y \in S^*$, there exists $k \in \mathbb{N} \setminus \{0\}$ such that $kx - y > F(S)$. Then, $z := kx - y \in S^*$ and $kx = y + z$.
